title: How much did 'The Pilgrim's Progress' affect you? - Quora

response.answer_text: I don’t recall that it affected me all that much, simply because it merely illustrated what I already very strongly believed. I am an atheist now, but when I first read a child’s illustrated version of Pilgrim’s Progress years ago, I was very much involved in the kind of church that believed pretty much the same things as the book’s author. I do remember being moved at the courage and perseverance of the religious believer who submitted to being burned at the stake for his faith. It hadn’t been all that long since I had read Foxe’s Book of Martyrs, a copy owned by my grandfather. You may know that Pilgrim’s Progress and Foxe’s book are two of the most popular religious works ever published in English. Anyway, I took it as a given that their outlook was the right one. I do remember being irritated at the author’s censure of Mr. Talkative, who joined the pilgrims on their journey for a short time and remarked that an effect of grace in the heart was to cause a great outcry against sin. Well, in a Christian context, that is perfectly true, but the other pilgrims found his declaration insufficiently pious and censured him as trivial and unfeeling. That struck me as a meaningless quibble and, though I probably did not realize it at the time, reflected my growing discomfort at the undercurrent of anti-intellectualism that runs through that kind of religion and of which I was slowly becoming aware, even if not at a fully conscious level. I reread the book again years later, as an adult; I think I was still very much involved in church, though of a more liturgical type than I had been in previously. In any case, I still admired the book for its religious viewpoint. I still appreciate it as a classic of English literature, though of course I no longer agree with its basic outlook. For any who haven’t read it, Hawthorne’s witty short story “The Celestial Railroad,” is a satire on Transcendentalism, based on the imagery of The Pilgrim’s Progress. The Celestial Railroad

The Pilgrim’s Progress is religious science fiction and it profoundly affected me because it is a very imaginative, symbolic, metaphysical interpretation of the Bible. The author, John Bunyan, is as talented as William Shakespeare (my view) or Lewis Carroll, the author of Alice in Wonderland (my view). Pilgrim’s Progress is told as a dream.
